page.title: 07FISH MARKETING
page.content: In the past the catches were taken to {Falmouth}where the fishermen received a penny or two for a crab; very little by today's standard. Later, fish was taken to{Billingsgate Market}in London by rail. Today the fish is taken to {Newlyn}for auction, or sold to {wholesale fish merchants}who pay a price approximating to market prices. Dwindling catches mean that 2 men today must work 150 pots and 40 to 50 nets to catch a similar amount as two men years ago working only 60 pots and 4 to 6 nets. The size of the catches nowadays are much smaller, but this is offset by the higher prices obtained for the fish. Coverack boats are registered in Falmouth, their numbers being preceeded by 'FH', the first and last letters of the port of registration.
